H0.text: Hydrogen, nitrogen, and carbon are the atoms whose clusters are rearranged when the body digests plant sugars to make glycogen.

H1.text: Oxygen, sulfur, and carbon atoms are rearranged in clusters when the body digests plant sugars to make glycogen, a way humans store energy.

H2.text: Carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen atoms are rearranged when the body digests plant sugars to make glycogen, a way humans store energy.

H3.text: Nitrogen, carbon, and sulfur are the atoms whose clusters are rearranged when the body digests plant sugars to make glycogen, a way humans store energy.

A4.text: For the simplest carbohydrates, the carbon-to-hydrogen-to-oxygen atomic ratio is 1:2:1, i.e. they are often represented by the empirical formula (CH2O)n.

A5.text: Plants synthesize carbohydrates from carbon dioxide and water by photosynthesis storing the absorbed energy internally, often in the form of starch or lipids.
